courses.name: Greek and Latin in English
courses.description: A survey of the influence of Greek and Latin upon English literary, scientific, technical, legal and medical vocabulary.  Emphasis is upon building competency with complex English words while studying the cultural influence of the classical languages on modern vocabulary.

courses.name: Classical Mythology
courses.description: Myths of Greece and Rome in literature and art.

courses.name: Classical Mythology - Honors
courses.description: Myths of Greece and Rome in literature and art.

courses.name: Classical Mythology - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: Myths of Greece and Rome in literature and art.

courses.name: Classical Mythology - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Myths of Greece and Rome in literature and art.

courses.name: Topics in Classical Humanities
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Greek Culture
courses.description: Survey of Greek life and thought. Principal developments in literature, the arts, politics, religion and philosophy, and their influence on Western civilization.

courses.name: Greek Culture - Honors
courses.description: Survey of Greek life and thought. Principal developments in literature, the arts, politics, religion and philosophy, and their influence on Western civilization.

courses.name: Roman Culture
courses.description: Survey of Roman life and thought. Principal developments in literature, the arts, politics, religion, philosophy, and private life, and their influence on Western Civilization.

courses.name: Greek Classics in Translation
courses.description: Reading in translation and critical study of the most important literary works of the ancient Greek World.

courses.name: Greek Classics in Translation
courses.description: Reading in translation and critical study of the most important literary works of the ancient Greek world.

courses.name: Roman Classics in Translation
courses.description: Reading in translation and critical study of the most important literary works of the ancient Roman world.

courses.name: The Origins of Music in the Ancient World
courses.description: Explores the use of music in the earliest historical societies, from the earliest evidence up to the fall of the Roman empire. Topics will include the history of musical instruments, the earliest scores, the development of music theory, the origins of melody, rhythm, and harmony, and the relationship between music, politics, and religion. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Service Learning in Classical Studies
courses.description: Students provide enrichment programming on the Ancient World at various Columbia Public School sites. Participants must be Classical Studies majors or minors. Graded on A/F basis only. Does not meet Arts and Science general education requirements.

courses.name: Foreigners and Dangerous Women in Greek and Latin Literature
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3130). The study of how Greek and Roman writers depicted and reacted to other races and cultures, compared them with their own, and thereby revealed their own values and prejudices.

courses.name: Foreigners and Dangerous Women in Greek and Latin Literature - Honors
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3130). The study of how Greek and Roman writers depicted and reacted to other races and cultures, compared them with their own, and thereby revealed their own values and prejudices.

courses.name: Foreigners and Dangerous Women in Greek and Latin Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3130). The study of how Greek and Roman writers depicted and reacted to other races and cultures, compared them with their own, and thereby revealed their own values and prejudices.

courses.name: Topics in Classical Humanities
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Topics in Classical Humanities - Honors
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Topics in Classical Humanities - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Ancient Western Philosophy
courses.description: (same as PHIL 3000). Philosophical thought on nature, knowledge, the gods, human life and society, from Thales to Augustine. Emphasis on Plato and Aristotle. The relevance of the ancients to contemporary life.

courses.name: Philosophy Before Socrates
courses.description: A study of the origin of philosophical thinking in the Ancient Greek world.  Topics to be explored include the nature of reality and our knowledge of it, the structure and constituents of the cosmos, human excellence and its relation to morality, political power, and happiness.

courses.name: Philosophy Before Socrates - Honors
courses.description: A study of the origin of philosophical thinking in the Ancient Greek world.  Topics to be explored include the nature of reality and our knowledge of it, the structure and constituents of the cosmos, human excellence and its relation to morality, political power, and happiness.

courses.name: The Age of Pericles
courses.description: A study of the literature and culture of the 5th and early 4th centuries B.C. in Athens. Authors will include Thucydides, Herodotus, Xenophon, Plato, Aristotle, the tragedians and Aristophanes.

courses.name: The Age of Pericles - Honors
courses.description: A study of the literature and culture of the 5th and early 4th centuries B.C. in Athens. Authors will include Thucydides, Herodotus, Xenophon, Plato, Aristotle, the tragedians and Aristophanes.

courses.name: The Age of Augustus
courses.description: Study of the literature of the Age of Augustus; Vergil, Ovid, Horace, Livy, and Propertius.

courses.name: The Age of Augustus - Honors
courses.description: Study of the literature of the Age of Augustus; Vergil, Ovid, Horace, Livy, and Propertius.

courses.name: Power and Oratory in Ancient Greece
courses.description: Concentrates on the rise of oratory in Greece and how oratory was exploited for political ends. Special attention will be paid to the Athenian Democracy in the fifth and fourth centuries BC.

courses.name: Power and Oratory in Ancient Greece - Honors
courses.description: Concentrates on the rise of oratory in Greece and how oratory was exploited for political ends. Special attention will be paid to the Athenian Democracy in the fifth and fourth centuries BC.

courses.name: Roman Comedy, Wit and Humor
courses.description: Study of works illustrating the comedy, wit and humor of the Romans: readings in comedies of Plautus and Terence, Catullus, Ovid's Metamorphoses,  Petronius' Satyricon, Martial, Juvenal and Macrobius.

courses.name: Greek and Roman Epic
courses.description: A study of the major representatives of the ancient epic genre. Readings will include Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Apollonius' Argonautica, Vergil's Aeneid.

courses.name: Greek and Roman Epic - Honors
courses.description: A study of the major representatives of the ancient epic genre. Readings will include Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Apollonius' Argonautica, Vergil's Aeneid.

courses.name: Greek Drama
courses.description: Reading and interpretation of Greek tragedies and comedies in translation.

courses.name: Greek Drama - Honors
courses.description: Reading and interpretation of Greek tragedies and comedies in translation.

courses.name: Advanced Mythology
courses.description: Interpretation of selected classical myths and their influence on later literature and art.

courses.name: Advanced Mythology - Honors
courses.description: Interpretation of selected classical myths and their influence on later literature and art.

courses.name: Murder and Mayhem: Images of Justice in Classical Antiquity
courses.description: Ideas of justice from Homer through the early Roman Empire; personal vengeance, law courts and trials, philosophical attitudes, women and courts, techniques of persuasion.

courses.name: Murder & Mayhem: Images of Justice in Classical Antiquity - Honors
courses.description: Ideas of justice from Homer through the early Roman Empire; personal vengeance, law courts and trials, philosophical attitudes, women and courts, techniques of persuasion.

courses.name: Murder and Mayhem: Images of Justice in Classical Antiquity - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Ideas of justice from Homer through the early Roman Empire; personal vengeance, law courts and trials, philosophical attitudes, women and courts, techniques of persuasion.

courses.name: Greek and Roman Characters and Ideals
courses.description: Study of selected types of characters admired and imitated or hated and rejected in classical antiquity; heroes, philosophers, women.

courses.name: Greek and Roman Characters and Ideals - Honors
courses.description: Study of selected types of characters admired and imitated or hated and rejected in classical antiquity; heroes, philosophers, women.

courses.name: War and Democracy in Late 5th c. BCE Athens
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3550).  Explores the discourse on war and peace in Athenian texts and art that survives from the last quarter of the 5th century B.C.E.  This was a period of relentless warfare: the Athenians were fighting the Spartans, Sparta's allies, unaligned cities and several of their own subject states.

courses.name: The Ancient Novel
courses.description: Reading and analysis of Greek and Latin prose fiction: ideal and comic romance, fantasy, romantic biography; Hellenistic background.

courses.name: The Ancient Novel - Honors
courses.description: Reading and analysis of Greek and Latin prose fiction: ideal and comic romance, fantasy, romantic biography; Hellenistic background.

courses.name: Paganism and Christianity
courses.description: A study of the transition from Paganism to Christianity in the Roman Empire, as seen by observers contemporary with the events.

courses.name: Paganism and Christianity - Honors
courses.description: A study of the transition from Paganism to Christianity in the Roman Empire, as seen by observers contemporary with the events.

courses.name: Paganism and Christianity - Writing Intensive
courses.description: A study of the transition from Paganism to Christianity in the Roman Empire, as seen by observers contemporary with the events.

courses.name: Women in the Ancient World
courses.description: Using classical literary texts as the central focus this course examines the role of women: the conflict inherent in their obligations and their identity in the context of these obligations.

courses.name: Women in the Ancient World - Honors
courses.description: Using classical literary texts as the central focus this course examines the role of women: the conflict inherent in their obligations and their identity in the context of these obligations.

courses.name: Classics in a Cross-Cultural Context
courses.description: The goal of this course is to place classical literature in a multicultural context by studying Greek and Latin literary texts alongside verbal art from non-European as well as European cultures.

courses.name: Classics in a Cross-Cultural Context - Honors
courses.description: The goal of this course is to place classical literature in a multicultural context by studying Greek and Latin literary texts alongside verbal art from non-European as well as European cultures.

courses.name: The Ancient World on Film
courses.description: (same as AR_H_A 3775 and FILM_S 3775).  This course explores how classical antiquity has been represented in twentieth and twenty-first-century film, with particular emphasis on the ways in which ancient narratives and iconography have been appropriated by filmmakers to address contemporary cultural issues.

courses.name: The Ancient World on Film - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as AR_H_A 3775 and FILM_S 3775).  This course explores how classical antiquity has been represented in twentieth and twenty-first-century film, with particular emphasis on the ways in which ancient narratives and iconography have been appropriated by filmmakers to address contemporary cultural issues.

courses.name: Sports and Spectacles in Greco-Roman Antiquity
courses.description: Investigates athletic display in ancient Greek and Roman culture, from its earliest representations in Greek literature to the massive spectacles of the Roman empire, with an emphasis on the intersections between sport and spectacle and other areas of ancient cultural life.

courses.name: Topics in Classical Humanities
courses.description: Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Greece: From the Bronze Age to the Byzantine Empire
courses.description: Study abroad in Greece, in conjunction with the MU International Center. Immersion in the physical and intellectual heritage of ancient Greece; emphasis on cross-disciplinary, on-site learning and the intersections among ancient, Byzantine, and modern Greece. Application required. Graded on A/F basis only.

courses.name: Greece: From the Bronze Age to the Byzantine Empire - Honors
courses.description: Study abroad in Greece, in conjunction with the MU International Center. Immersion in the physical and intellectual heritage of ancient Greece; emphasis on cross-disciplinary, on-site learning and the intersections among ancient, Byzantine, and modern Greece. Participants chosen by instructor. Graded on A/F basis only. Application required.

courses.name: Greek and Roman Religion
courses.description: (same as REL_ST 4500). Survey of religious development among the Greeks and Romans.

courses.name: Greek and Roman Religion - Honors
courses.description: (same as REL_ST 4500). Survey of religious development among the Greeks and Romans.

courses.name: Literature and Culture of the Hellenistic Age
courses.description: (cross-leveled with CL_HUM 7550). A survey of the literature and culture of the Hellenistic Age.

courses.name: Literature and Culture of the Hellenistic Age - Honors
courses.description: A survey of the literature and culture of the Hellenistic Age.

courses.name: The Classical Tradition
courses.description: Selected studies in continuity and influence of Greek and Roman culture on Middle Ages, Renaissance, and modern times.

courses.name: The Classical Tradition - Honors
courses.description: Selected studies in continuity and influence of Greek and Roman culture on Middle Ages, Renaissance, and modern times.

courses.name: The Classical Tradition - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: Selected studies in continuity and influence of Greek and Roman culture on Middle Ages, Renaissance, and modern times.

courses.name: The Classical Tradition - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Selected studies in continuity and influence of Greek and Roman culture on Middle Ages, Renaissance, and modern times.

courses.name: The World of Late Antiquity
courses.description: (cross-leveled with CL_HUM 7650). A survey of the literature, culture, and history of the late Roman and early Byzantine periods. Attention to Christianity's development and the transformation of the classical heritage.

courses.name: The World of Late Antiquity - Honors
courses.description: A survey of the literature, culture, and history of the late Roman and early Byzantine periods. Attention to Christianity's development and the transformation of the classical heritage.

courses.name: Oral Tradition
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 4770). Study of verbal art from living oral traditions (e.g. Native American and African American) and important literary works with roots in oral tradition (e.g. the Bible, the Iliad and Odyssey, and Beowulf).

courses.name: Oral Tradition - Honors
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 4770). Study of verbal art from living oral traditions (e.g. Native American and African American) and important literary works with roots in oral tradition (e.g. the Bible, the Iliad and Odyssey, and Beowulf).

courses.name: Political Thought in Classical and Christian Antiquity
courses.description: (same as POL_SC 4800).  Reading and discussion of Greek, Roman, and Early Christian treatises on politics and political life. Survey of the political institutions and procedures of the Greek city states and Roman Republic and Empire. Examination of contemporary Christian responses and adaptations.

courses.name: Capstone in Classical Humanities
courses.description: Culminating course in the study of Greek and Roman literature and Classical Culture.  Required for Classical Humanities majors in first term of senior year.

courses.name: Capstone in Classical Humanities- Honors
courses.description: Culminating course in the study of Greek and Roman literature and Classical Culture.  Required for Classical Humanities majors in first term of senior year.

courses.name: Topics in Classical Humanities
courses.description: Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.
courses.prerequisites: any Classical Humanities 3000 level course or instructor's consent

courses.name: Literature and Culture of the Hellenistic Age
courses.description: (cross-leveled with CL_HUM  7550). A survey of the literature and culture of the Hellenistic Age. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: The World of Late Antiquity
courses.description: (cross-leveled with CL_HUM 4650). A survey of the literature, culture, and history of the late Roman and early Byzantine periods. Attention to Christianity's development and the transformation of the classical heritage.
